Elliotte Harold wrote:

> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
> > I understand you don't believe in polluting the public API, but saying
> > that that suggestion won't solve the problem is ridiculous.
>
> It won't. There is already a test. That test is breaking. Once you have
> a breaking test you don't change the API in any way until you've fixed
> the breakage. This is a basic principle of test driven development. This
> has nothing to with making things public or not.

JUnit can be used in many more contexts than test-driven development, 
bless its soul.

That said, when using test-driven development, I have often written a 
test, and had it break in a way that indicates I don't know what's going 
on somewhere else (a private method, maybe).  So, I now have two things 
I don't know, leading to two possibilities:

1) Delete (or comment out) the first test, and write a test for the 
private method, so I can figure out what's going on there first.

2) Introduce a seam to protect me for now from the private method.  
Figure out how to run the higher-level method without running the 
private method, so that I can handle the higher-level method first.

I used to believe in a third alternative: hack away with print 
statements and a debugger until I get my head around both of these 
things I don't know, and possibly more than seven others.  I no longer 
believe that's a good use of my time.

    David Saff
